mailed 4 26 43
Recvd 5 3 43
24
Easter Evening the 25th.
Sidney Darling,
It is now seven P.M. and I have just finished washing the dishes
with Melle. and Miss Evans. We have had supper with the dining room doors wide
open looking out at our little plot of grass and daffodils. A lovely spring eve-
ning! and a lovely Easter day.
Landine and I went ot church as I told you in my letter this morning
-Tom could not find a taxi any where so he did not turn up. The service was short
as there was communion after[,]so Landine and I left right after the sermon and we
went and called on Aunt Mary who wanted very much to see Landine. Aunt Mary looks
very well but complains a great deal about her poor health. Her garden was a mass
of apple blossoms and tulips[,]and was so pretty.
Tom Evans met us at my house and we took all the easter eggs over
to Helens[,]and got there for lunch with about t[e]n other people. Serge Obelinsky[in
the parachute troops], some people called Fisher I did not know, Avie, the Lester
Armours, and Lowmans. Af[t]er lunch we hid ten pounds of peanuts for the children-
The McKim tribe, Sonia Dill[,] and Legendres. The babys hunted for the eggs and the
older kids for the peanuts. They [h]ad a lovely time, and it was like a three ring
circus. The men did gardening at one end of the garden, planting vegetables and
watering. The dogs chased cats about and the children hunted around the panzies and
violets for peanuts. It was great fun, and everyone went home with candy and easter
bunnies and full of ice cream and cake in their tummies. The only part I missed was
exercise. I did not get any exercise to-day which I must say is what I always want
most on Sunday. Unfortunately there was no time.
Tom Evans took the train back to Philla. this evening, and I am
here at my desk writing to you. Bo has gone to bed and Landine is trying to do some
home work on arithmatic which seems to be a great trial to her.
Landine goes back to Middleburg by buss to-morrow afternoon. I
must say I have never seen her looking better. She really looks the picture of heal[h]
this time. She is getting awfully big, and I think will be tall. She has been havin[g]
riding lessons right along, and is learning to jump too. She is going to ride in
the Foxcroft horse show in amfew weeks. Miss Charlotte [h]as her over every Wendesday
now for lunch, and she is going to have her baptised next week with alot of other
kids which will be nice of her. She seems anxious to be baptised and I think as
there are others doing the same thing- its a good idea. It is going to be in Miss
Charlotte's house. Miss Charlotte called me up and told me about it and was very a
amusing. She said Landine had told her that perhaps if she was baptised "the devil
would go out of her". Miss Charlotte afreed that perhaps it might.
I think that you are right about sending both Bo and Landine to
Foxcroft next year if I do go away-[God knows if I will ever get away].I do think
Miss Charlotte understands children so well and ismsuch a good influence that you
cant beat it no matter what Landine wants. I believe if Miss LCHarlotte will have
them that is the best salution. I shall plan on that. New York would probably be
unwise and less of a benifit in the long run. That Hill school is excellent and
she is stufdying ever so much better than she ever has before.
[She has chosen Tom Eastman as god-father- which amused me to death [and] I can't
wait to write [and] tell him- Aunt Katherine she has chosen as god-mother with
Miss Charlotte of course as the other one.]
[End Page 1]
2
Well darling I wish I was with you this evening and could find out
how you are, how your back feels etc. I would like so much to be with you. I wonder
when that day will come. I long for your news but I have not called you up on the
telephone as I know you dont like it[,] and it is sort of hard to talk and ask what
one wants to ask, but I always get such a thrill to hear your voice that it seems
to me worth it.
I am hoping to get a l tter to-morrow telling me all about your 
new office and your self. I do hope the postman will not dissappoint me.
It would be so marvelous if you could walk into this room this
evening and sitbeside me on the sofa. Your flowers are all around the room, tulips,
snapdragons and irises.They are so heavenly and everything is attractive and cosy
of should be-,it is n't,because you are not here to make it it so. When I sit by
myself in the living I always go straight to the typewriter and write you as I can 
not sit by myself and just think and relax. Its too lonely[,] so I must write to you
and talk to you[,] and tell you how much I love you[,]and miss you sweet ears.It makes
you seem so much closer to [me]
I am in the midst of writing for reservations for the summer for
the children. The Narragansett Inn has quoted such high prices -I am writing to
other Inns and also the Narragansett to find out what sort of reservation one can
make. A beach is the answer to children's summer I think[,] and Rhode Island
certainly agreed with Bo last summer. She has nto had one cold all winer insp[i]te
of the flue and awful colds that have been r[a]ging around Washington. Ofcourse
Miss Evans is amazing at keeping Bo in the pink[,]and she has her alredy shininer her
sandles and doing things for herself. We are so lucky in having Miss Evans. I assue
you she is a dream.
I sent Rose to New York over Easter to [be] with Sherin but I think
sh[e] will be back to-morrow.
I wish I had some interesting news for you[,]but I am afraid I
have not. The war news looks tough and hard and slow,although everyone feels we
are atleast on the road to victory in the Atlantic inspite of the submarines.
To-morrow starts an other week- the last of April and soon May
will be upon us, and then the heat of a Washington summer- and so it goes. I would
give alot to see a field,ora beach, or a mountain, but I guess I will live in the
inside of Q bldg. for many a moon.
I was amused yesterday when a delegation appeared in my office
to ask Madame Legendre whether the french written on the page was idiomatic and
and correct. I read it over and said I did not understand what "crampan" was. They
nearly died as they thought I was french, and had come to me for the correct
translation I had a good laugh and spent most of the rest of the afternoon going
with them from office to,office trying to find the correct word for some technical
railroad equipment which noon seemed to be able to solve. We had Larousse diction[ary]
but that was not what they wanted.They wanted to french idium[,]not just dictionary
stuff that might not be the way the ordinary man could understand it. Well it turnd
out all the french everyone spoke was about my speed and no better[,]and we never did
get to a conclusion. I had quite alot of fun over it, and thought it was amusingt-
that they believed I was pure french and would solve their trouble.
I laughed over the sencor asking "what was behind your wife
sending you flowers"?- the significance of it? Dont they gatherits because I love
you very much darling- thats why. Its pretty amusing is n't it?
It is now eight-thirty and Landine is about to go to bed so I
shall also.We sleep in the same room as I might just as wll.
All love to you,my darling- always your- Gertrude
[End Page 2]
